title-group.article-title: Adaptive trajectory tracking control design with command filtered compensation for a quadrotor

article-meta.aff: Seventh Research Division, Science and Technology on Aircraft Control Laboratory, Beihang University, Beijing, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Zuo Zongyu, Seventh Research Division, Science and Technology on Aircraft Control Laboratory, Beihang University (formerly Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics), Beijing, People's Republic of China Email: zzybobby@buaa.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The design of a flight controller capable of not only stabilizing attitude but also tracking a trajectory accurately for a quadrotor aircraft in presence of parametric uncertainties and external disturbances is more challenging than that in the absence of uncertainties. In this paper we propose an adaptive trajectory tracking control algorithm, based on the relationship between attitude and linear acceleration, using online adaptive approximator to estimate unknown aerodynamic parameters and external disturbance upper bounds, and a linear tracking-differentiator to eliminate the timescale separation assumption between attitude and linear dynamics in control system design. The stability of the closed-loop control system is proven subsequently. Finally, the validity and the improvement of this proposed algorithm relative to the previous work are demonstrated through numerical simulations of tracking a circular trajectory under several conditions, including basic parametric uncertainty, exogenous wind disturbance and control input oscillation eliminating via a hyperbolic tangent function instead of a sign function.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: A quadrotor unmanned aircraft, consisting of four individual rotors in an â€˜Xâ€™ arrangement, is capable of vertical take-off and landing (VTOL), but it does not require complex mechanical linkages, such as swash plates and teeter hinges, that commonly appear in typical helicopters. Thus, the quadrotor is an attractive rotary-wing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) for both military and civilian usages.

Pounds et al. (2002), Hamel et al. (2002) and McKerrow (2004) studied the dynamical model of the four-rotor VTOL vehicles without considering the aerodynamic effects which were investigated and validated by Hoffmann et al. (2004, 2007). Tayebi and McGilvray (2004) designed an attitude stabilization PD2 controller based on the unit quaternion description (Joshi et al. 1995; Lizarralde and Wen 1996). Bouabdallah et al. (2004) applied respectively classic PID and LQ algorithms to the quadrotor attitude control. Compared with full-actuated attitude control problem, the under-actuated and the strong coupling properties of this kind aircraft render the trajectory tracking control more involved. Despite various trajectory tracking design methodologies (Bouabdallah and Siegwart 2005; Waslander et al. 2005; Madani and Benallegue 2006a,b; Besnard et al. 2007; Pollini L andMetrangolo A 2008), little attention has been paid to the influence of using a two-timescale separation assumption. It is assumed that the craft attitude response â€˜aimsâ€™ the thrust immediately such that the attitude velocity and acceleration dynamics can therefore be ignored within small enough sampling time. However, the two timescale separation assumption needs large inner loop gain to guarantee the closed-loop stability (Schumacher and Khargonekar 1998) and the closed-loop stability is very sensitive to the parameter selection, especially the inner loop gain. Zuo (2010b); Zuoet al. (2010) introduced a tracking-differentiator (TD) in the trajectory tracking control design to eliminate timescale separation assumption and showed the improvement in tracking stability and robustness as well as the alleviation of sensitivity to parameter selections, but no rigorous stability analysis was given. Thelatest literature due to Lee et al. (2010) proposed a nonlinear geometric tracking controller on SE(3) without introducing timescale separation and showed almost global desirable closed-loop properties, but the model uncertainties, to which the geometric control was usually sensitive, were not considered. In view of the external uncertainties and unknown dynamics,sliding mode technique was widely employed invarious trajectory tracking control algorithms (Bouabdallah and Siegwart 2005; Waslander et al. 2005; Madani and Benallegue 2006b; Besnard et al. 2007) for a quadrotor. However, this kind of robust controller designs are very conservative when the information of the disturbance upper-bound cannot be exactly obtained. Pollini L and Metrangolo A (2008) proposed a robust backstepping controller based on the idea of practical stability instead of Lyapunov stability to deal with nonlinearities, measurement disturbance and actuator failure, but the convergence of tracking error was proved into a confined area around the origin. Huang et al. (2010) proposed a tracking controller via standard backstepping with the aid of adaptive control to estimate the unknown mass-related parameter of a quadrotor, but assumed that the aerodynamic effect coefficients are accurately known. In recent years, several quadrotor related papers have presented their experimental flight results. The nonlinear trajectory tracking control strategies, proposed by Kendoul et al. (2007); Kendoul (2009); Kendoul et al. (2009b) were performed by a real-time autonomous flight and showed great autonomous capability of taking off, hovering and landing. The control law designs of Kendoul et al. (2007) and Castillo et al. (2004) adopted a nested-saturation technique (Teel 1992) to account for the actuator saturation limit explicitly and gave the analytical expressions of parameter selection. These nonlinear controller syntheses, the design parameter selections and the stability proofs were quite intricate.

This paper adopts a hierarchical design strategy to build the relationship between the attitude and linear acceleration. A new command filtered backstepping with the aid of online approximators used to estimate the aerodynamic parameters and external uncertainties, as well as a linear tracking differentiator to obviate the dependence on time scale separation are employed. Actually, the paper presents a further result on the quadrotor trajectory tracking control accounting for parametric uncertainty and external disturbance which were ignored in the model and the control design by Zuo (2010b). Compared with previous controllers, the proposed control algorithm has the following properties: (1) online approximation to the parametric uncertainty and the external disturbance upper-bound; (2) global asymptotic stability of position tracking; (3) less sensitivity of the parameter selections by eluding the timescale separation assumption between outer and inner loops; and (4) less dependency on the mathematical model by introducing command filtered compensation in backstepping.

This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 presents the dynamical modeling of the quadrotor. Sections 3 and 4 present an adaptive trajectory tracking control design algorithm. In Section 5 numerical simulation results of a quadrotor trajectory tracking are discussed. Finally the conclusion of the proposed trajectory tracking control design algorithm is presented in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. Quadrotor mathematical model
sec.p:
The quadrotor is a typical under-actuated, nonlinear coupled system in control terms. In order to compensate for the effect of the reaction torques, the four rotors are divided into two pairs of (1, 3) and (2, 4) turning in the opposite directions, as depicted in Figure 1. Hence, the quadrotor is suitable for hovering and quasi-static flight conditions. The quadrotor flight mechanism is that: vertical motion is created by collectively increasing and decreasing the speed of all four rotors; pitch or roll motion is achieved by the differential speed of the frontâ€“rear set or the leftâ€“right set of rotors, coupled with lateral motion; yaw motion is realized by the different reaction torques between the (1, 3) and (2, 4) rotors. So the number of individual manipulating variables cannot instantaneously set the accelerations in all directions of the configuration space. Figure 1.
Quadrotor aircraft concept.

Let â„â€‰=â€‰{Oexeyeze} denote an Earth-fixed inertial frame and ğ’œâ€‰=â€‰{Oxyz} denote a body-fixed frame whose origin O is located at the center of mass of the quadrotor, as shown in Figure 1. The quadrotor attitude is defined by three Euler angles Î˜â€‰=â€‰(Ï•, Î¸, Ïˆ)T, and Râ€‰âˆˆâ€‰SO(3) denotes the orthogonal rotation matrix to orient the quadrotor: R=(CÎ¸CÏˆSÎ¸CÏˆSÏ†-SÏˆCÏ†SÎ¸CÏˆCÏ†+SÏˆSÏ†CÎ¸SÏˆSÎ¸SÏˆSÏ†+CÏˆCÏ†SÎ¸SÏˆCÏ†-CÏˆSÏ†-SÎ¸CÎ¸SÏ†CÎ¸CÏ†) where S(Â·) â‰œ sin(Â·), C(Â·) â‰œ cos(Â·). The quadrotor kinematic equations (Zuo 2010a,b) can be expressed as (1)pÂ·=Îµ (2)Î˜Â·=WÎ© where p denotes the absolute position of the origin of frame ğ’œ, Îµ the linear velocity of the center of mass expressed in frame â„, Î© the three rotations, the matrix W is defined as follows: W=(1SÏ†TÎ¸CÏ†TÎ¸0CÏ†-SÏ†0SÏ†/CÎ¸CÏ†/CÎ¸) where TÎ¸ â‰œ tan Î¸. Thus, the matrix W is nonsingular if the pitch angle satisfies Î¸â€‰â‰ â€‰(2kâ€‰âˆ’â€‰1)Ï€/2, (kâ€‰âˆˆâ€‰ğ’µ).
As for the dynamic modeling of a quadrotor, two reasonable assumptions are made as follows.

statement.title: Assumption 1
statement.p: The quadrotor fuselage is a rigid body. Then the derivation of nonlinear dynamics can be obtained using Newtonâ€“Euler formulas.

statement.title: Assumption 2
statement.p: The quadrotor structure is symmetric with respect to the plane Oxz and Oyz, which results in a moment of inertial tensor with just diagonal inertial terms.

sec.p: The dynamic equations can be expressed as (3)mÎµÂ·=-mgez+Faero+TRez (4)IfÎ©Â·=-Î©Ã—IfÎ©-Ga+Taero+Ï„a where m denotes the quadrotor mass, g the gravity acceleration, ezâ€‰=â€‰(0, 0, 1)T the unit vector in frame â„, and T=âˆ‘i=14fi=bâˆ‘i=14Ï‰i2 the total thrust produced by the four rotors. The reaction torque caused by air drag is given by Qi=kÏ‰i2, where Ï‰i denotes the speed of the rotor i, the parameters b and k are positive proportionality constants relative to the density of air, the shape of the blades, the number of blades, the chord length of the blades, the pitch angle of the blade airfoil and the drag coefficient.

Under Assumption 2, the total inertial matrix IfâˆˆR3Ã—3 is a symmetrical positive-definite constant matrix expressed in frame ğ’œ. The vector Ga=âˆ‘i=14Ir(Î©Ã—ez)(-1)i+1Ï‰i denotes the gyroscopic torque. Faero and Taero are the aerodynamic drag (Madani and Benallegue 2006a,b) (5){Faero=Kt(Îµ-Îµair)Taero=Kr(Î©-Î©air) where {Kt, Kr} are two unknown diagonal aerodynamic matrices and {Îµair, Î©air} are the components of linear and angular velocity with respect to the air mass, expressed in frame â„ and frame ğ’œ, respectively. Let d denote the distance from the rotors to the center of mass. Then the control torques generated by the four rotors are (6)Ï„a=(Ï„a1Ï„a2Ï„a3)=(bd(Ï‰42-Ï‰22)bd(Ï‰32-Ï‰12)k(Ï‰22+Ï‰42-Ï‰12-Ï‰32))

In view of the aerodynamic uncertainty, Equations (1)â€“(4) are arranged together and rewritten as follows: (7){pÂ·=ÎµÎ˜Â·=WÎ©ÎµÂ·=-gez+m-1(KtÎµ+TRez+d1)Î©Â·=If-1(-Î©Ã—IfÎ©-Ga+KrÎ©+Ï„a+d2) where di(iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2) denotes the external disturbance and let d1â€‰=â€‰âˆ’KtÎµairâ€‰=â€‰(d11, d12, d13)T and d2â€‰=â€‰âˆ’KrÎ©airâ€‰= (d21, d22, d23)T which satisfy the following assumptions.

statement.title: Assumption 3
statement.p: Uncertainty terms d1 and d2 remain bounded in any specified operating envelope ğ’Ÿ, i.e. supğ’Ÿ{|dij|}â€‰â‰¤â€‰lij, and lijâ€‰=â€‰constâ€‰>â€‰0 (iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2; jâ€‰=â€‰1, 2, 3).

statement.title: Assumption 4
statement.p: Aerodynamic coefficients Kt and Kr areconstant or slow time varying at low speed, i.e. KÂ·tâ‰ˆKrÂ·â‰ˆ0.

statement.title: Remark 1
statement.p: Note that the terms d1 and d2 can also be modeled as total external disturbing force and torque, including external disturbance of aerodynamic drag.

sec.title: 3. Adaptive trajectory tracking control design methodology
sec.p: The control objective is to design a controller such thatall of the closed-loop signals are bounded andthe tracking error â€–p(t)â€‰âˆ’â€‰pc(t)â€– converges to the origin asymptotically, where pc(t):[0,âˆ)â†’R3 is a designated sufficiently smooth time-varying desired trajectory with its time-derivatives bounded.

The hierarchical design scheme divides the quadrotor control problem into position tracking control and attitude stabilization control designs, both of which arebased on adaptive backstepping technique. First, theposition tracking control design aims to realize the desired trajectory tracking and obtain corresponding control thrust input as well as an attitude commanded signal. The subsequent attitude stabilization control design focuses on tracking the attitude commanded signal to satisfy the need of position control and finally synthesizes the control torque input to the quadrotor. The closed-loop stability of the trajectory tracking in presence of model parametric uncertainties and external disturbances is proved via the use of Lyapunov theory and Barbalat lemma (Khalil 2002) and summarized in Theorem 1 of Section 4. The control design methodology is depicted in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Control block diagram.

Let {Kâˆ§t,Kâˆ§r,lâˆ§1,lâˆ§2} denote the approximations to the unknown parameters {Kt, Kr, l1, l2}, and then define the following approximation errors K~t=Kâˆ§t-Kt,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒK~r=Kâˆ§r-Kr,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒl~1=lâˆ§1-l1,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒl~2=lâˆ§2-l2 where l1â€‰=â€‰(l11, l12, l13)T and l2â€‰=â€‰(l21, l22, l23)T denote the unknown upper-bounds of the external disturbances.

sec.title: 3.1. Position tracking control design
sec.p: Define the position error Z1=p-pc where the vector pc is the commanded position vector. Choose the candidate Lyapunov function as V1=12Z1TK1Z1 where K1 is symmetric and positive definite. Taking the time derivative of V1 yields (8)VÂ·1=Z1TK1ZÂ·1=Z1TK1(Îµ-pÂ·c) where Îµ can be regarded as a virtual control signal and devised as Îµc=pÂ·c-Z1. Define the velocity error Z2â€‰=â€‰Îµâ€‰âˆ’â€‰Îµc, which leads to ZÂ·1=-Z1+Z2. Construct the compound Lyapunov-like function V2=12Z1TK1Z1+12Z2TZ2+12tr(K~tTÎ“1-1K~t)+12l~1TÎ“2-1l~1 where the adaptation gains Î“i-1>0(i=1,2) are symmetric and tr(Â·) is the trace of matrix (Â·). Differentiating both sides of V2 versus time,1 we have (9)VÂ·2=Z1TK1ZÂ·1+Z2TZÂ·2+trg(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·tg)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1=-Z1TK1Z1+Z2Tg(K1Z1-gez+1mKtÎµ+1md1+uT-ÎµÂ·c)g+trg(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·tg)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1+Z2Tg(K1Z1-gez+1mKtÎµ+uT-ÎµÂ·cg)+1mâˆ‘i=13|z2i||d1i|+trg(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·tg)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1+Z2Tg(K1Z1-gez+1mKtÎµ+uT-ÎµÂ·cg)+1mâˆ‘i=13z2isign(z2i)l1i+trg(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·tg)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1=-Z1TK1Z1+Z2Tg(K1Z1-gez+1mKtÎµ+uT-ÎµÂ·c+1mSign(Z2)l1g)+trg(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·tg)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1 where Sign(Z2)â€‰=â€‰diag{sign(z21), sign(z22), sign(z23)}, and uT â‰œ TRez/m denotes the virtual control signal and can be selected as (10)uT=ÎµÂ·c-K1Z1-K2Z2-1mKâˆ§tÎµ-1mSign(Z2)lâˆ§1+gez=pÂ·Â·c-(K1-E)Z1-(K2+E)Z2-1mKâˆ§tÎµ-1mSign(Z2)lâˆ§1+gezâ‰œU+gez such that (11)VÂ·2â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2-1mZ2TK~tÎµ-1mZ2TSign(Z2)l~1+tr(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·t)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1=-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2+tr(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·t-1mK~tTZ2ÎµT)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1-1mZ2TSign(Z2)l~1â€ƒ=-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2+tr[K~tTÎ“1-1(K~Â·t-1mÎ“1Z2ÎµT)]+l~1TÎ“2-1(l~Â·1-1mÎ“2Sign(Z2)Z2) where K2 is a symmetric positive-definite matrix and EâˆˆR3Ã—3 is an identity matrix, and (12)U=(U1,U2,U3)T=pÂ·Â·c-(K1-E)Z1-(K2+E)Z2-1mKâˆ§tÎµ-1mSign(Z2)lâˆ§1 is an auxiliary term. Let the adaptation laws be (13)Kâˆ§Â·t=K~Â·t=1mÎ“1Z2ÎµT,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒlâˆ§Â·1=l~Â·1=1mÎ“2Sign(Z2)Z2 The time derivative of V2 along solutions of the closed-loop dynamics defined by (1), (3) and (13) is VÂ·2â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2â‰¤0. This implies 0â€‰â‰¤â€‰V2(âˆ)â€‰â‰¤ V2(t)â€‰â‰¤â€‰V2(t0)â€‰<â€‰âˆ, âˆ€tâ€‰â‰¥â€‰t0â€‰â‰¥â€‰0. By the definition of V2, the preceding inequality can be rewritten as 0â‰¤Î»Â¯1â€–Z1â€–22+Î»Â¯2â€–Z2â€–22+Î»Â¯(Î“1-1)â€–K~tâ€–22â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ+Î»Â¯(Î“2-1)â€–l~1â€–22â‰¤V2(t0)<âˆ where the notation Î»(Â·) denotes the smallest eigenvalue of matrix (Â·) and Î»i â‰œ Î»(Ki) for iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2, 3, 4. Thisimplies Z1âˆˆLâˆ,Z2âˆˆLâˆ,K~tâˆˆLâˆ,l~1âˆˆLâˆ. Integrating VÂ·2, we obtain Î»Â¯1âˆ«t0âˆâ€–Z1â€–22dt+Î»Â¯2âˆ«t0âˆâ€–Z2â€–22dtâ‰¤â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ-âˆ«t0âˆVÂ·2(t)dtâ‰¤V2(t0)-V2(âˆ)â‰¤V2(t0)<âˆ which shows that Z1â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’2, Z2â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’2. The second time derivative of the Lyapunov function V2 is VÂ·Â·2â‰¤2Z1TK1Z1-2Z1TK1Z2+2Z2TK2K1Z1â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ+2Z2TK22Z2+2mZ2TK2[K~tÎµ+Sign(Z2)lâˆ§1-d1] which is bounded because we have Îµ=Z2+Îµc=Z2-Z1+pÂ·câˆˆLâˆ, and Assumptions 3 and 4 imply that d1â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ and lâˆ§1=l~1+l1âˆˆLâˆ. Therefore, the function dV2/dt is uniformly continuous. The Barbalat lemma implies that dV2/dtâ€‰â†’â€‰0 as tâ€‰â†’â€‰âˆ which requires that the errors Z1 and Z2 approach zero as time approaches infinity. However, the online approximation errors K~t and l~1 are only bounded and do not necessarily converge to their real values.

Equation (10) can be rewritten as (14)RT(U+gez)=1mTez After simple algebraic computation of (14), the following equations are acquired (15)U1CÎ¸CÏˆ+U2CÎ¸SÏˆ-(U3+g)SÎ¸=0 (16)U1(SÎ¸CÏˆSÏ†-SÏˆCÏ†)+U2(SÎ¸SÏˆSÏ†+CÏˆCÏ†)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ+(U3+g)CÎ¸SÏ†=0 (17)U1(SÎ¸CÏˆCÏ†+SÏˆSÏ†)+U2(SÎ¸SÏˆCÏ†-CÏˆSÏ†)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ+(U3+g)CÎ¸CÏ†=1mT In virtue of the assumption that cos Î¸ is nonzero, divide both sides of (15) by cos Î¸ and then the pitch attitude can be computed as (18)Î¸=arctan(U1CÏˆ+U2SÏˆU3+g) Equation (17)â€‰Ã—â€‰sin Ï•â€‰âˆ’â€‰(16)â€‰Ã—â€‰cos Ï• yields (19)1mTsinÏ†=U1SÏˆ-U2CÏˆ Employing (14), we have the following relationship: (1mTez)T(1mTez)=(U+gze)T(U+gze) which is equivalent to U12+U22+(U3+g)2=(1mT)2 Combining the preceding equation with (19) yields the roll attitude expression: (20)Ï†=arcsin(U1SÏˆ-U2CÏˆU12+U22+(U3+g)2) To this end, (18) and (20) can be used to compute the attitude commanded inputs to the inner loop. Hence, the closed-form expressions for pitch and roll attitudes are, respectively, g{Î¸c=arctang[(U1CÏˆc+U2SÏˆc)/(U3+g)g]Ï†c=arcsing[g(U1SÏˆc-U2CÏˆcg)/g(U12+U22+(U3+g)2g)g] where Ïˆc is the commanded yaw attitude. In addition, the required total lift generated by the four rotors can be calculated from (17): (21)T=mg[U1(SÎ¸CÏˆCÏ†+SÏˆSÏ†)+U2(SÎ¸SÏˆCÏ†-CÏˆSÏ†)gg+(U3+g)CÎ¸CÏ†g]

sec.title: 3.2. Attitude stabilization control design
sec.p: Define the attitude tracking error Z3=Î˜-Î˜c, where Î˜c denotes the commanded attitude signals. Construct the Lyapunov candidate function V3=Z3TZ3/2, the time derivative of which along the trajectory of (2) is VÂ·3=Z3TZÂ·3=Z3T(WÎ©-Î˜Â·c). Although the commanded signals Î˜c are known, it is quite complicated and boring to solve analytically derivative signals of the commanded attitudes. To avoid the intricate calculation and alleviate the dependence on two timescale separation assumption between attitude and linear dynamics in this paper, a linear TD is proposed to estimate the derivative instead of computing Î˜Â·c exactly: (22){XÂ·1=X2XÂ·2=-2Î›X2-Î›2(X1-Î˜c) where the gain matrix Î›â€‰=â€‰diag{Î³1, Î³2, Î³3}â€‰>â€‰0 shall be large enough to guarantee the fast tracking to the commanded attitude derivative signals. The estimated version of the derivative is denoted by Î˜âˆ§Â·c=X2.

statement.title: Remark 2
statement.p: The so-called â€˜linear TDâ€™ is actually a low-pass filter of the transfer function W(s)=Î³2s2+2Î³s+Î³2, where Î³ is a tracking speed factor. The step response of this linear Hurwitz system of such a structure is non-overshooting and exponentially stable (Han 2008).

sec.p: Select the angular velocity Î© as a virtual control signal and construct the desired angular velocity as (23)Î©d=W-1(Î˜âˆ§Â·c-K3Z3) where K3 is also a symmetric positive-definite matrix. In order to avoid tediously taking time derivative of Î©d and alleviate the dependence on analytic model, the first-order command filter (Farrell et al. 2009; Dong et al. 2011) (24)Î©Â·c=-TÂ¯(Î©c-Î©d) is employed to track the desired angular velocity Î©d. The filter gain matrix TÂ¯=diag{tÂ¯1,tÂ¯2,tÂ¯3}>0 should belarge enough to promise the fast tracking. Define the angular velocity tracking error Z4â€‰=â€‰Î©â€‰âˆ’â€‰Î©c, where the commanded value Î©c is used in place of the desired angular velocity Î©d. In consideration of the influence caused by the command filter, a new vector Î» is introduced to compensate for the tracking error in the rigorous stability analysis: (25)Î»Â·=-K3Î»+W(Î©c-Î©d)=WÎ©c+K3(Z3-Î»)-Î˜âˆ§Â·c So the modified attitude tracking error is ZÂ¯3=Z3-Î». Choose the compound Lyapunov-like function as V4=12ZÂ¯3TZÂ¯3+12Z4TZ4+12tr(K~rTÎ“3-1K~r)+12l~2TÎ“4-1l~2 Similarly, taking time derivative of V4 along the vector fields of (2) and (4) yields VÂ·4=-ZÂ¯3TK3ZÂ¯3+ZÂ¯3TÎ˜~Â·c+Z4Tg[WTZÂ¯3-If-1(Î©Ã—IfÎ©)gg-If-1Ga+If-1KrÎ©+If-1d2+If-1Ï„a-Î©Â·cg]+trg(K~rTÎ“3-1K~Â·rg)+l~2TÎ“4-1l~Â·2â‰¤-ZÂ¯3TK3ZÂ¯3+ZÂ¯3TÎ˜~Â·c+Z4Tg[WTZÂ¯3-If-1(Î©Ã—IfÎ©)gg-If-1Ga+If-1KrÎ©+Sign(Z4)If-1l2+If-1Ï„a-Î©Â·cg]+trg(K~rTÎ“3-1K~Â·rg)+l~2TÎ“4-1l~Â·2 where Sign(Z4) â‰œ diag{sign(z41), sign(z42), sign(z43)}, Î˜~Â·câ‰œÎ˜âˆ§Â·c-Î˜Â·c. Extract the control torque Ï„a as (26)Ï„a=(Î©Ã—IfÎ©)+Ga-IfWTZÂ¯3-Kâˆ§rÎ©-Sign(Z4)lâˆ§2+IfÎ©Â·c-IfK4Z4 and select the adaptation laws as (27)Kâˆ§Â·r=K~Â·r=Î“3If-1Z4Î©T,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒlâˆ§Â·2=l~Â·2=Î“4If-1Sign(Z4)Z4 such that VÂ·4â‰¤-ZÂ¯3TK3ZÂ¯3+ZÂ¯3TÎ˜~Â·c-Z4TK4Z4â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ‰¤-âˆ‘i=13k3i|zÂ¯3i|(|zÂ¯3i|-k3i-1|Î¸~Â·ci|)-Z4TK4Z4 where K4 is symmetric and positive definite. If |zÂ¯3i|>k3i-1|Î¸~Â·ci| (iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2, 3), the time derivative of V4 isnegative definite so that ZÂ¯3âˆˆLâˆ,Z4âˆˆLâˆ,K~râˆˆLâˆ,l~2âˆˆLâˆ. Usually the response of the linear TD is much faster than the variation of the commanded attitude, and thus assume that within finite time there exist time t1 and a small constant vector Ïµ â‰œ (Ïµ1, Ïµ2, Ïµ3)T such that |Î¸~Â·ci|â‰¤Îµi,â€ƒâˆ€t>t1>0. Then if |zÂ¯3i|â‰¥k3i-1Îµi one has VÂ·4â‰¤-Z4TK4Z4, which implies that Z4â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’2. The second time derivative of the Lyapunov function V4 is VÂ·Â·4â‰¤2Z4TK42Z4+2Z4TK4If-1g[K~rÎ©+Sign(Z4)lâˆ§2-d2+WTZÂ¯3g] On the one hand, using (14) one can verify that Uâ€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ according to the preceding proof, and therefore the commanded pitch and roll are bounded while the commanded yaw attitude is designated, i.e. Î˜câ€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ. Note that the command filter (24) assures Î©câ€‰â†’â€‰Î©d. It follows that the filter compensated error Î»â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ. From (22) the bounded modified attitude tracking error ZÂ¯3 implies that Z3=ZÂ¯3+Î»âˆˆLâˆ. Because the estimated derivative signal Î˜âˆ§Â·c approaches Î˜Â·c asymptotically, the boundedness of Î©d can be obtained through (19). It follows that Î©câ€‰â†’â€‰Î©dâ€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ. Thus, Î©â€‰=â€‰Z4â€‰+â€‰Î©c is bounded. On the other hand, in view of Assumptions 3 and 4, d2â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ and lâˆ§2=l~2+l2âˆˆLâˆ can be obtained. Now one can verify that d2V4/dt2 is bounded and dV4/dt is uniformly continuous. Using the Barbalat lemma again, it follows that dV4/dtâ€‰â†’â€‰0 as tâ€‰â†’â€‰âˆ which implies that limtâ†’âˆ Z4â€‰=â€‰0.

statement.title: Remark 3
statement.p: The finite bandwidth of the specified linear TD results in bounded approximation error to the derivative of the commanded attitude, i.e. |Î¸~Â·ci|â‰¤Îµi, so that the attitude tracking errors satisfy |z3i|-|Î»i|â‰¤|zÂ¯3i|â‰¤k3i-1|Î¸~Â·ci|â‰¤k3i-1|Îµi|, i.e. the attitude tracking error will ultimately converge to the set Qâˆˆ{âˆ€Î¸i||z3i|â‰¤k3i-1|Îµi|+|Î»i|,i=1,2,3}, where z3iâ€‰=â€‰Î¸iâ€‰âˆ’â€‰Î¸ci and (Î¸1, Î¸2, Î¸3)T â‰œ (Ï•, Î¸, Ïˆ)T. Hence, the attitude tracking error Z3 is uniformly ultimate bounded.

statement.title: Remark 4
statement.p: It is also possible to decrease the magnitude of the bound of the attitude tracking error zÂ¯3i by choosing large K3, although sometimes it may be not desirable in consideration of the closed-loop bandwidth.

sec.p: Substituting the expressions (23) and (24) into the control torque expression (26), one obtains (28)Ï„a=(Î©Ã—IfÎ©)+Ga-IfTÂ¯Î©c+IfTÂ¯W-1Î˜âˆ§Â·c-IfTÂ¯W-1K3(Î˜-Î˜c)-IfWT(Î˜-Î˜c-Î»)-IfK4(Î©-Î©c)-Kâˆ§rÎ©-Sign(Z4)lâˆ§2

sec.title: 4. Control algorithm and parameter settings
sec.p: The adaptive trajectory tracking control design with command filtered compensation for a quadrotor is summarized in the following theorem.

statement.title: Theorem 1
statement.p: Let the overall quadrotor system in the presence of parametric uncertainties and external disturbances be given by (7). The online adaptive approximation-based trajectory tracking controller (12), (13), (21), (22)â€“(24), (27) and (28) under Assumptions 1â€“4 results in all signals of the closed-loop control system bounded, and stabilizes the trajectory tracking error â€–p(t)â€‰âˆ’â€‰pc(t)â€– asymptotically.

statement.title: Proof
statement.p: Select the following positive-definite function (29)V=12(Z1TK1Z1+Z2TZ2+ZÂ¯3TZÂ¯3+Z4TZ4)+12[tr(K~tTÎ“1-1K~t)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~1+tr(K~rTÎ“3-1K~r)+l~2TÎ“4-1l~2] Taking the time derivative of the function V along the trajectories of (7) with the controller (12), (21), (22)â€“(24), (28) and the online approximator (13), (27) yields (30)VÂ·â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2-âˆ‘i=13k3i|zÂ¯3i|(|zÂ¯3i|-k3i-1|Î¸~Â·ci|)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ-Z4TK4Z4 If |zÂ¯3i|â‰¥k3i-1|Î¸~Â·ci|, then VÂ·â‰¤0 so that Z1â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ, Z2â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ, ZÂ¯3âˆˆLâˆ, Z4â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ, K~tâˆˆLâˆ, K~râˆˆLâˆ, l~1âˆˆLâˆ, andl~2âˆˆLâˆ. Within finite time, there exist time t1 and asmall constant vector Ïµ such that |Î¸~Â·ci|â‰¤Îµi,âˆ€t>t1>0. Then if |zÂ¯3i|â‰¥k3i-1Îµi one has VÂ·â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2-Z4TK4Z4. Similar to the previous proof, we have Z1â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’2, Z2â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’2, Z4â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’2. Thesecond time derivative d2V/dt2 is bounded. TheBarbalat lemma ensures limtâ†’âˆ Z1â€‰=â€‰limtâ†’âˆ Z2â€‰=â€‰limtâ†’âˆ Z4â€‰=â€‰0, which implies that the trajectory tracking error â€–p(t)â€‰âˆ’â€‰pc(t)â€– is asymptotically stable. The modified attitude tracking error ZÂ¯3 ultimately converges to the set Q~âˆˆ{âˆ€Î¸~i||z~3i|â‰¤k3i-1|Îµi|,i=1,2,3}â–¡

statement.title: Remark 5
statement.p: The proof shows that the asymptotical convergence of the trajectory tracking error does not require the convergence of the attitude tracking error Z3 or the modified one ZÂ¯3 to zero. In addition, the bounded approximation errors do not mean that the estimated parameters converge to their real values.

statement.title: Remark 6
statement.p: The expressions (21) and (28) include the component of sign function so that the control inputs are discontinuous in nature, which induces high-frequency switching dither. Since the high-frequency oscillation will excite the unmodeled high-frequency dynamics of the quadrotor in practice, either a saturate function or switch-like hyperbolic tangent function can be employed to eliminate the chattering phenomenon but to induce a boundary layer.

sec.p: In view of the defect as discussed in Remark 7, a hyperbolic tangent function-based trajectory tracking control algorithm for the quadrotor is presented in Theorem 2.

statement.title: Definition 1
statement.p: A hyperbolic tangent function is defined as tanh(x)=exp(x)-exp(-x)exp(x)+exp(-x), where independent variable xâˆˆR and exponential function exp(x)âˆˆR+. The hyperbolic tangent function satisfies the following properties: (1) |tanh(x)|â€‰â‰¤â€‰1; (2) |tanh(x)|â€‰=â€‰0 if and only if xâ€‰=â€‰0.

statement.title: Definition 2
statement.p: A hyperbolic tangent function matrix is defined as Tanh(x) â‰œ diag{tanh(x1), tanh(x2), tanh(x3)}, where xâ€‰=â€‰(x1, x2, x3)T. The hyperbolic tangent function matrix satisfies â€–Tanh(ax)â€–â‰¤3,â€ƒâˆ€a>0.

statement.title: Theorem 2
statement.p: Let the overall quadrotor system in presence of parametric uncertainties and external disturbances be given by (7). The hyperbolic tangent function-based trajectory tracking controller (31){U=pÂ·Â·c-(K1-E)Z1-(K2+E)Z2-1mKâˆ§tÎµâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ-1mTanh(aZ2)lâˆ§1T=m[U1(SÎ¸CÏˆCÏ†+SÏˆSÏ†)+U2(SÎ¸SÏˆCÏ†-CÏˆSÏ†)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ+(U3+g)CÎ¸CÏ†] (32)Ï„a=(Î©Ã—IfÎ©)+Ga-IfTÂ¯Î©c+IfTÂ¯W-1Î˜âˆ§Â·c-IfTÂ¯W-1K3(Î˜-Î˜c)-IfWT(Î˜-Î˜c-Î»)-IfK4(Î©-Î©c)-Kâˆ§rÎ©-Tanh(aZ4)lâˆ§2 with online adaptive approximator (33){Kâˆ§Â·t=1mÎ“1Z2ÎµT,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒlâˆ§Â·1=1mÎ“2Tanh(aZ2)Z2Kâˆ§Â·r=Î“3If-1Z4Î©T,â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒlâˆ§Â·2=Î“4If-1Tanh(aZ4)Z4 under Assumptions 1â€“4 results in all signals of the closed-loop control system bounded, and stabilizes the trajectory tracking error â€–p(t)â€‰âˆ’â€‰pc(t)â€– asymptotically.

statement.title: Proof
statement.p: Select the same positive-definite function as (29), the time derivative of which along the trajectories of (7) is VÂ·=VÂ·2+VÂ·4â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1+Z2Tg(K1Z1-gez+1mKtÎµ+uT-ÎµÂ·cgg+1mSign(Z2)l1g)-ZÂ¯3TK3ZÂ¯3+ZÂ¯3TÎ˜~Â·c+Z4Tg[WTZÂ¯3-If-1(Î©Ã—IfÎ©)-If-1Gagg+If-1KrÎ©+Sign(Z4)If-1l2+If-1Ï„a-Î©Â·cg]+trg(K~tTÎ“1-1K~Â·tg)+l~1TÎ“2-1l~Â·1+trg(K~rTÎ“3-1K~Â·rg)+l~2TÎ“4-1l~Â·2 Using (31), we have uTâ€‰=â€‰Uâ€‰+â€‰mgez. Substituting uT, (32) and adaptive law (33) into VÂ· yields (34)VÂ·â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2-ZÂ¯3TK3ZÂ¯3-Z4TK4Z4+1mZ2T[Sign(Z2)-Tanh(aZ2)]l1+ZÂ¯3TÎ˜~Â·c+Z4T[Sign(Z4)-Tanh(aZ4)]If-1l2â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Z2TK2Z2-ZÂ¯3TK3ZÂ¯3-Z4TK4Z4+23mZ2Tl1+ZÂ¯3TÎ˜~Â·c+23Z4TIf-1l2â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Î»Â¯2â€–Z2â€–2(â€–Z2â€–2-23â€–l1â€–2Î»Â¯2m)-Î»Â¯3â€–ZÂ¯3â€–2(â€–ZÂ¯3â€–2-â€–Î˜~Â·câ€–2Î»Â¯3)-Î»Â¯4â€–Z4â€–2(â€–Z4â€–2-23â€–l2â€–2Î»Â¯4â€–Ifâ€–2)â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1-Î»Â¯*â€–Z*â€–2(â€–Z*â€–2-Î²*) where Î»*â€‰=â€‰min{Î»2, Î»3, Î»4}, Z*=(Z2,ZÂ¯3,Z4)T andÎ²*=max{23â€–l1â€–2Î»Â¯2m,â€–Î˜~Â·câ€–2Î»Â¯3,23â€–l2â€–2Î»Â¯4â€–Ifâ€–2}. If â€–Z*â€–â€‰â‰¥â€‰Î²*, VÂ·â‰¤-Z1TK1Z1 is negative definite. Similar to the proof of Theorem 1, we obtain Z1â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆâ€‰âˆ©â€‰â„’2, Z2â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ, ZÂ¯3âˆˆLâˆ, Z4â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ, K~tâˆˆLâˆ, K~râˆˆLâˆ, l~1âˆˆLâˆ, l~2âˆˆLâˆ and d2V/dt2â€‰âˆˆâ€‰â„’âˆ. The Barbalat lemma implies that limtâ†’âˆ Z1â€‰=â€‰0, i.e. trajectory tracking error is asymptotically stable.â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ–¡

statement.title: Remark 7
statement.p: The asymptotical convergence of the trajectory tracking error Z1 does not require the asymptotical convergence of Z2, ZÂ¯3 and Z4 which are actually ultimately bounded by Î²*. In addition, the scalar a is a positive design parameter which governs the approximation rate to the sign function.

sec.p: The design parameters of the adaptive trajectory tracking controller proposed in Theorem 1 include position tracking controller gains K1 and K2, attitude stabilization controller gains K3 and K4, linear TD gain Î›, command filter gain TÂ¯, adaptation gains Î“1â€“Î“4, and an additional parameter a in Theorem 2. The guidelines for the parameter selection are summarized as follows: without inner/outer loop timescale separation, the theory of this paper only requires each Ki (iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2, 3, 4) to be positive definite, so the attitude and the position control gains can be selected independently to satisfy their own bandwidth, which is different from the timescale separation case in Zuo (2010) that larger inner loop gains than outer loop ones are needed to guarantee the closed-loop stability. In Zuo (2010a) simulation comparison demonstrated that having control gains of the inner loop no larger than those of the outer loop results in closed-loop unstableness of the trajectory tracking. The selection of linear TD and command filter gains TÂ¯ and Î› should be a compromise between the control energy and the tracking speed, that is, the larger TÂ¯ and Î› lead to faster tracking but larger control energy. It should be noted that Î› should be larger than TÂ¯ for the reason that the computation of the desired angular velocity Î©d needs the commanded attitude rate signal Î˜Â·c which is estimated by linear TD. The adaptation gains are selected by trial and error. Basically, large Î“i results in fast online approximation to the unknown aerodynamic coefficients and external disturbance bounds, however, great adaptation speed will deteriorate the quadrotor closed-loop stability. Therefore, the selection of adaptation gains relies on the bandwidth of the whole closed-loop system.

statement.title: Remark 8
statement.p: Small quadrotor aircraft is very sensitive to actuator saturation. In view of payload constraints, the aircraft's motors are chosen such that the quadrotor operates close to its physical limits. If the combination of these design parameters still cannot satisfy the quadrotor physical constraints such as magnitude, rate and bandwidth, an alternative way is to integrate the constraints into the command filter to guarantee the whole stability (Farrell et al. 2003, 2005).

sec.title: 5. Simulation results
sec.p:
In order to verify the validity of the control algorithm proposed in this paper, several Matlab/Simulink simulations of tracking typical trajectory are performed using data given by Tayebi and McGilvray (2004), as listed in Table 1. For simplicity the dynamics of DCmotor is ignored, since the commercial DC motor has its own controller with good response. The controller parameters in simulation are fixed at K1â€‰=â€‰K3â€‰=â€‰diag{0.36, 0.36, 0.36}, K2â€‰=â€‰K4â€‰=â€‰diag{1.2, 1.2, 1.2}, Î“1â€‰=â€‰diag{0.1, 0.1, 0.1}, Î“2â€‰=â€‰diag{10âˆ’3, 10âˆ’3, 10âˆ’3}, Î“3â€‰=â€‰diag{0.01, 0.01, 0.01} and Î“4â€‰=â€‰diag{10âˆ’5, 10âˆ’5, 10âˆ’5}. The filter gain matrices are chosen as TÂ¯=diag{15,15,15} and Î›=2TÂ¯. In view of the limitations of real measuring device, the sampling time is fixed to â–µtâ€‰=â€‰0.01 s. The initial attitude and the approximation parameters (Kâˆ§t,Kâˆ§r,lâˆ§1,lâˆ§1) are zero, so are the linear and the angular velocities, respectively. However, the initial position is located at p0â€‰=â€‰(5,0, 0)T. The real values of the aerodynamic coefficients Kt and Kr used in the simulation model are Ktâ€‰=â€‰diag{10âˆ’2, 10âˆ’2, 10âˆ’2} and Krâ€‰=â€‰diag{10âˆ’3, 10âˆ’3, 10âˆ’3}. The considered desired trajectory is a circular path of 0.5 m high, given by pcâ€‰=â€‰(5 cos(0.1t), 5 sin(0.1t), 0.5)T. Table 1.
Quadrotor unmanned aircraft model parameters-
Parameter m g l Ir Ix Iy Iz b k
Value 0.468 9.81 0.225 3.357â€‰Ã—â€‰10âˆ’5 4.856â€‰Ã—â€‰10âˆ’3 4.856â€‰Ã—â€‰10âˆ’3 8.801â€‰Ã—â€‰10âˆ’3 2.98â€‰Ã—â€‰10âˆ’6 1.14â€‰Ã—â€‰10âˆ’7
Units kg m/s2 m kgÂ·m2 kgÂ·m2 kgÂ·m2 kgÂ·m2 N Â· s2/rad2 Nm Â· s2/rad2

sec.title: 5.1. Basic flight condition: parametric uncertainty
sec.p:
To illustrate the performance of the control law developed herein suffering from model parametric uncertainty, the simulation result under such a baseline flight condition without external disturbances (i.e. Îµairâ€‰=â€‰Î©airâ€‰=â€‰0) is presented in Figure 3, which shows that the proposed trajectory tracking controller works well, although the online estimated parameters such as Kâˆ§t and Kâˆ§r do not converge to their real values. Note that in spite of the fact that there is no external wind, not all of the estimated bounds of the disturbances are zero, such as li1 and li2 (iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2), which coincides with the theorem proof in Section 4 that the asymptotical convergence of the tracking error does not guarantee the convergence of the approximated error to the origin. To make a comparison with the controller designed by Zuo (2010b), Figure 4 presents the tracking errors under the same basic flight condition. From Figure 4(a) we find that the trajectory tracking error of the control system designed in this paper is asymptotically stable, while from Figure 4(b) the tracking exhibits a stable error mainly resulting from the ignorance of the unknown aerodynamic effects in the control law design by Zuo (2010b). Figure 3.
Flight without external disturbances.
Figure 4.
Trajectory tracking control.

sec.title: 5.2. Flight simulation under parametric and small exogenous disturbance uncertainties
sec.p:
To test the robustness of the online approximator to both parametric uncertainty and external disturbance, small wind disturbances are set to Îµairâ€‰=â€‰(0.1, 0,0)T and Î©airâ€‰=â€‰(0, 0, 0.1)T in the simulation. Other simulation settings and initial conditions remain unchanged. Figure 5 gives the time histories of system states, control inputs, estimated parameters and bounds of the external disturbances under a small wind, and the approximation to the unknown ones converges asymptotically around some fixed values despite not being the true ones. Figure 6(a) shows that the trajectory tracking error converges to zero asymptotically. However, the oscillating phenomenon caused by the discontinuous control law can be observed from Figure 3(b) and Figure 5(c), which may deteriorates the flight performance in practice. Figure 5.
Flight simulation under a small exogenous disturbance.
Figure 6.
Position tracking errors.

sec.title: 5.3. Dither elimination via a continuous hyperbolic tangent function
sec.p:
To eliminate the switching dither caused by discontinuous control law in practice, the hyperbolic tangent function-based trajectory tracking controller proposed in Theorem 2 is employed in simulation. The hyperbolic tangent function parameter is chosen as aâ€‰=â€‰2, and the adaptation gains are modified as Î“iâ€‰=â€‰diag{1, 1, 1} (iâ€‰=â€‰1, 2, 3, 4). The other design parameters and the disturbance are the same as described in Section 5.2. Figure 7 shows that this modification of the control approach provides a good trajectory tracking throughout. By contrast, we can see that the control input oscillation disappears. This is because the hyperbolic tangent function is continuous and smooth, and provides another freedom to design parameter a to approach the sign function in practice. As illustrated in Figure 6(b), the trajectory tracking error still converges to zero asymptotically. Figure 7.
Dither elimination using a hyperbolic tangent function.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper we have described an adaptive trajectory tracking control algorithm for a small quadrotor unmanned aircraft. The proposed adaptive backstepping-based control design, motivated by extending the basic controller designed by Zuo (2010a,b) to the case of existing model uncertainties and external disturbances, still exploited the configuration of the rotorcraft unmanned vehicles between attitude and linear dynamics and employed a linear TD to avoid the two timescale separation assumption between inner attitude loop and outer position loop, and further used an online adaptive approximator to achieve robustness to parametric uncertainty and external disturbance. The asymptotic stability property has been proven for the closed-loop system by Theorem 1 using a Lyapunov method and the Barbalat lemma, which is not given by Zuo (2010b). Extensive simulations were performed that showed that the trajectory tracking can be accomplished in the closed-loop system in spite of uncertainties in the aerodynamic parameter and exogenous disturbance in a complicated environment. A practical consideration of using continuous function in place of switching function in the control law was also proved in Theorem 2 and illustrated via simulation.

fn.p: The matrix differentiation operations (Petersen and Pedersen 2008) used in the paper are summarized in the Appendix.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The author sincerely acknowledges the motivating discussions with Professor HUO Wei of the Seventh Research Division, Beihang University.

sec.title: Appendix
sec.p: Let aijâˆˆR,â€ƒi=1,2,â€¦,m,â€ƒj=1,2,â€¦,n. Then the ordered rectangular array A=(a11a12â€¦a1na21a22â€¦a2n:::am1am2â€¦amn) is said to be a real matrix of dimension mâ€‰Ã—â€‰n.

statement.title: Proposition 1
statement.p: The scalar Î± is given by the quadratic form Î±=xTAx where x is nâ€‰Ã—â€‰1, A is nâ€‰Ã—â€‰n, and A dose not depend on x, then âˆ‚Î±âˆ‚x=xT(A+AT)

statement.title: Proof
statement.p: By definition Î±=âˆ‘j=1nâˆ‘i=1nÎ±ijxixj Differentiating with respect to the kth element of x we have âˆ‚Î±/âˆ‚xk=âˆ‘j=1nakjxj+âˆ‘i=1naikxi for all kâ€‰=â€‰1, 2,â€¦, n and, consequently, âˆ‚Î±âˆ‚x=xTAT+xTA=xT(A+AT)â–¡

statement.title: Proposition 2
statement.p: For the special case where A is a symmetric matrix and Î±=xTAx where x is nâ€‰Ã—â€‰1, A is nâ€‰Ã—â€‰n, and A dose not depend on x, then âˆ‚Î±âˆ‚x=2xTA

statement.title: Proof
statement.p: This is an obvious application of Proposition 1 using the definition of a symmetric matrix Aâ€‰=â€‰AT.â€ƒâ–¡
